Dead.synopsis: An SwD dialog for the Gnome leader at the Duergar Camp. He can be killed during combat either trying to escape or helping players fight Duergar first, and Nere later.

Saved.synopsis: Dialog for gnome foreman on the other side of the ebon lake after they were saved by player. Mentions the other gnomes being kept at moonrise towers.
Saved.how_to_trigger: Repro steps:1. Start the game.2. loadlevel WLD_Main_A3. goto -634, 15, 3104. Ctrl+Shift+K the Cave-In (Nere will speak to you automatically)5. Select dialogue options "Stop! No more...", "I act on...", "You wouldn't dare...", then "You so much..."6. killcombat7. Speak with Beldron

individual_metadata.synopsis: The gnome leader's main dialogue. He thanks you for saving them, and tells you what brought his people to the Underdark to begin with - an expedition led by their charismatic leader Wulbren, to find a forgotten gnomish explosive of awesome power - runepowder.
individual_metadata.how_to_trigger: Resolve the cave-in situation in Grymforge by removing the rubble. A conflict ensues - this dialogue picks up on the various outcomes of that conflict.Repro steps:1. Start the game.2. loadlevel WLD_Main_A3. goto -635.141; 14.738; 3104. CTRL-Shift_K on the cave-in5. Resolve the dialog by killing NERE and the Duerqars6. Speak with Beldron

automatic_ordering.reasoning: There is a shared narrative event here: the cave‐in conflict. The gnome leader is central to this event and can either survive or be killed in combat. When he survives, the player can trigger his main dialogue (shown as the session with the empty key) in which he thanks you for saving his people, and later a conversation with the gnome foreman (the 'Saved' session) is available – implying that the leader’s survival and ensuing discussion is a prerequisite for the foreman dialogue. On the other hand, if the gnome leader is killed during the combat (using either an escape attempt or while helping fight Duergar/Nere), the dialogue designated as 'Dead' is triggered. This means that the two outcomes for the leader – his main dialogue versus his death dialogue – are mutually exclusive.

Dead_15.speaker: Narrator
Dead_15.text: *The corpse does not stir. It will answer no more questions.*

Dead_18.speaker: Player
Dead_18.text: What were you doing in the ruins?

Dead_17.speaker: Player
Dead_17.text: What happened to the rest of your people?

Dead_5.speaker: Beldron
Dead_5.text: Mithral Hall... dwarves took in... family...

Dead_8.speaker: Narrator
Dead_8.text: *The spell's power wanes. You can ask no more questions.*

Dead_19.speaker: Narrator
Dead_19.text: *The corpse seems willing to speak - but not to its killer.*

Saved_0.speaker: Beldron
Saved_0.text: We're moving on. There's... there's nothing left for us here.

Saved_1.speaker: Beldron
Saved_1.text: I knew little Thulla would survive all this. But... not like that.

Saved_2.speaker: Beldron
Saved_2.text: Never thought I'd owe a bunch o' mushrooms my life. Only wish the rest of my people were here.

Saved_3.speaker: Beldron
Saved_3.text: What a bloodbath. Safer here than in Grymforge though, no doubt about it.

Saved_4.speaker: Beldron
Saved_4.text: Thanks again for offing that drow. Only made it here 'cause of you. But I can't stop thinking about the rest of us...

Saved_5.speaker: Beldron
Saved_5.text: ... stuck in Moonrise with a bunch of sadists. Poor bastards.

10.speaker: Lunkbug
10.text: Beldron - I was so worried! Did Nere hurt you?

16.speaker: Beldron
16.text: No, no - I'm all right. Did the sergeant hurt you?

124.speaker: Lunkbug
124.text: Who cares? We're together now, thank Ironhand!
124.context: CinematicNodeContext: Addressed to Beldron. The two gnomes embrace, and then pull apart.

34.speaker: Beldron
34.text: We ought to thank someone a little closer by, I think.
34.context: NodeContext: Tired, wry - referencing the player when his husband thanks the gods

40.speaker: Beldron
40.text: Gaerdal Ironhand you may not be, but you damn well fight like him.
40.context: NodeContext: Impressed with you - someone thanked the war-god Ironhand and he's implying you're the next best thing

49.speaker: Beldron
49.text: I'm grateful, don't mistake me, but... why help us? You're one of them, aren't you?
49.context: NodeContext: Guarded, sizing the player up - he thinks we're one of the cultists

78.speaker: Beldron
78.text: You did just lift a mountain from our heads, so... good enough for me, I reckon.
78.context: NodeContext: Nodding, accepting - not going to look a gift horse in the mouth

89.speaker: Beldron
89.text: Here - the Ironhand Gnomes honour their debts. With Wulbren gone, that falls to me.
89.context: CinematicNodeContext: Standard 'handing reward' animation.NodeContext: Drawing himself up to perform a necessary obligation - doesn't see himself as leadership material but accepts the responsibility

60.speaker: Barcus Wroot
60.text: Make it quick! We need to find Wulbren - now.

92.speaker: Beldron
92.text: You're a little late, Barcus my lad. He's already been sent to Moonrise Towers.
92.context: NodeContext: Slight tone shift - he and Barcus have been at odds before. Beldron speaks down to Barcus VERY slighttly

77.speaker: Beldron
77.text: The leader of our expedition. He was sent off to Moonrise Towers.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: Wulbren's been taken to Moonrise Towers, I hear.

53.speaker: Beldron
53.text: Aye. The cult kept us for slave-hands, but Wulbren was our leader. He... knows things.
53.context: NodeContext: Hesitant to say exactly what Wulbren knows

98.speaker: Beldron
98.text: Things the cult would like to know too, it seems.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: I know someone looking for this Wulbren. Where is he?

58.speaker: Beldron
58.text: Taken to Moonrise Towers. The rest of us were set digging, but... Wulbren knows things. Seems the cult wants to know them too.
58.context: NodeContext: Hesitant to say exactly what Wulbren knows

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Keep the coin. It seems like you'll need it.

104.speaker: Beldron
104.text: No. Debt's a stone 'round your neck, and we Ironhands like to walk tall. We'll be fine.
104.context: NodeContext: Gently firm - too proud not to give you a reward

139.speaker: Beldron
139.text: It's Wulbren I'm worried for. He was sent on to Moonrise Towers.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Surely you can do me a little more honour than that.

137.speaker: Beldron
137.text: I wish I could. But most of our funds rested with our leader, Wulbren. He'll be in Moonrise Towers by now.

116.speaker: Beldron
116.text: We were just slave-hands to the cult, but not Wulbren. He... knows things. Things they want to know too.
116.context: NodeContext: Hesitant to say exactly what Wulbren knows

52.speaker: Barcus Wroot
52.text: What has he gotten himself mixed up in now...

85.speaker: Player
85.text: Would this have anything to do with runepowder?

136.speaker: Beldron
136.text: How did you... well, you're a sharp one. Most still believe it's a fairy tale - I know I did, once.
136.context: NodeContext: Surprised at how much you know, then deciding to spill the whole story

133.speaker: Beldron
133.text: But not Wulbren. He bloody found it - a small cache, buried down here with a manuscript.
133.context: NodeContext: Wonder/awe at his leader's perserverance

97.speaker: Player
97.text: Spare the secrecy. Philomeen already escaped with the runepowder.

103.speaker: Beldron
103.text: ... then it seems you've saved us twice over. Gods above - she bloody did it. Of course she did.
103.context: NodeContext: Mute astonishment - a friend of his managed to escape the slavers and bring some runepowder with her

91.speaker: Beldron
91.text: Wulbren has a way of attracting true believers - his quest for runepowder was the latest dream he stuffed in our heads.
91.context: NodeContext: Wry, but with a hint of weariness - Beldron believes in the cause, but he knew Wulbren in his youth, before he became a charismatic figure the other gnomes idolise

29.speaker: Beldron
29.text: And he was bloody right. He found it - a small cache sitting down here with a manuscript.
29.context: NodeContext: Some of his weariness melting away - he's seasoned, but still capable of feeling wonder when a myth is proved true

57.speaker: Player
57.text: If you're talking about runepowder, Philomeen already blew it up. And herself with it.

109.speaker: Beldron
109.text: ... a sad end. But a fitting one for a true believer. When Wulbren claimed that runepowder existed, she was the first to volunteer.
109.context: NodeContext: Mute grief, but not shock - an older man unsurprised by the fanaticism of the youths in his group

68.speaker: Player
68.text: Before you ask, no - I'm not going to stage a rescue.

67.speaker: Beldron
67.context: NodeContext: shrugging, a little defeated. This line trails off into another 'Much as I want to march after Wulbren myself... we can't.'

138.speaker: Player
138.text: Whatever the cult wants, I want the opposite. We need to free your friend.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: This is no time to be coy. What is that Wulbren knows?

24.speaker: Player
24.text: I also like to know things. Start talking.

128.speaker: Beldron
128.text: You'll call me mad, but... fine. Wulbren's found the formula for runepowder.
128.context: NodeContext: Considering a moment - then shrugging - 'what does he have to lose'

45.speaker: Beldron
45.text: Aye. The explosive of Gaerdal Ironhand's own creation. Fistfuls wiping out armies, all those old stories.
45.context: NodeContext: Confirming and pressing on, as if knwoing you'll disbelieve him and understanding why. Tone is 'Yes I know it's crazy, but true'

0.speaker: Beldron
0.text: Only Wulbren couldn't leave the stories be - so he went and bloody found it. A small supply, tucked away down here with a manuscript.
0.context: NodeContext: Wulbren is his charismatic leader

38.speaker: Beldron
38.text: He'd just made sense of the formula when the cult jumped us - so he burned the damn thing.
38.context: NodeContext: Revealing Wulbren did something nigh-on sacreligious

122.speaker: Beldron
122.text: If there's a single copy left, it's sitting in his head. Those Absolutists pull it out and make runepowder...
122.context: NodeContext: Ominous - the cult are likely to torture Wulbren for what he knows

63.speaker: Beldron
63.text: ... they could flatten the whole of the Sword Coast.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Then we'll just have to free him first.

30.speaker: Beldron
30.text: We have our own freedom to look to, I'm afraid. We'll take our chance when it arises, then back to the city.
30.context: NodeContext: His people are still enslaved - he needs to be pragmatic.

9.speaker: Beldron
9.text: Wulbren knew the risks when he came in search of runepowder. We all did.

1.speaker: Beldron
1.text: You really would, wouldn't you? But not us.
1.context: NodeContext: Sizing you up again - you've acted selflessly thus far and he's a little in awe - but he can't share you idealism

127.speaker: Player
127.text: How long do you think he can hold out?

108.speaker: Beldron
108.text: I'd rather not think about it. Besides, we have our own freedom to look to.
108.context: NodeContext: His people are still enslaved - he needs to be pragmatic.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: I don't plan on being anywhere nearby when they do.

120.speaker: Beldron
120.text: Wise, I think. Losing our leader is a blow, but we have our own freedom to look to.
120.context: NodeContext: His people are still enslaved - he needs to be pragmatic.

8.speaker: Beldron
8.text: As for Wulbren... we can only hope they'll make his end swift.

82.speaker: Beldron
82.text: Then we're of one mind, I think.

121.speaker: Beldron
121.text: My people can barely stand. And we have business back in the city.
121.context: NodeContext: Pragmatic - mentally moving on from the thought of saving Wulbren

47.speaker: Beldron
47.text: Business that sent us after the powder to begin with. The formula might be gone, but we still have the barrels.
47.context: NodeContext: Sighing, tired - thinking of a long struggle ahead

46.speaker: Beldron
46.text: That business is what sent us after the powder to begin with. Now... we'll have to make other arrangements.
46.context: NodeContext: Sighing, tired - thinking of a long struggle ahead

74.speaker: Barcus Wroot
74.text: And just like that, you'd leave Wulbren behind. I knew you lot were foolish, but I didn't know you were cruel.

35.speaker: Beldron
35.text: If you knew half as much as you think, my lad, Wulbren might have kept you around.
35.context: NodeContext: Again, talking down to Barcus. He pities him more than dislikes him

132.speaker: Player
132.text: Enough. Bickering won't save your friend.

54.speaker: Barcus Wroot
54.text: And neither will this twit, apparently.

20.speaker: Beldron
20.text: I've had fights enough for one day, Barcus.

12.speaker: Beldron
12.text: My people will find somewhere to regroup across the lake. Then on to the city.

96.speaker: Beldron
96.text: If you find yourself in Baldur's Gate, seek us out. We'll raise a glass to Wulbren together.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: You're just abandoning your leader? That's cold.

80.speaker: Beldron
80.text: It is. And if the pick swung the other way, I'd expect Wulbren to do the same.
80.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging he's leaving his friend behind -

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Run away, then. I have my own business to be about.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: If my path takes me to Moonrise, I'll see about freeing Wulbren myself.

90.speaker: Beldron
90.text: He'd admire your resolve. And your optimism.
90.context: NodeContext: Thinks the player's idealism is misplaced, but won't stand in their way

6.speaker: Player
6.text: If it's truly that powerful, then we can't let the cult have it.

5.speaker: Beldron
5.text: There's little we can do to stop them from here, I'm afraid. We have our own freedom to look to.
5.context: NodeContext: His people are still enslaved - he needs to be pragmatic.

7.speaker: Beldron
7.text: Maybe Wulbren can hold out. Either way, he's beyond our help now.

62.speaker: Beldron
62.text: I wouldn't trust them with a bloody butter knife. But it's a fight for another day.

37.speaker: Beldron
37.text: It doesn't matter. We can't help him from here.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Start explaining, or I start breaking bones.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: Are you always so suspicious of those who save you?

17.speaker: Beldron
17.text: I try not to need saving. Hasn't much worked out, as you can see.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: The cult thinks it owns me. I beg to differ.

56.speaker: Beldron
56.text: That didn't much look like begging. But no complaints from me.
56.context: NodeContext: Referencing the player's recent slaughter of his captors

18.speaker: Player
18.text: You say you're grateful - but my coinpurse is still light.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Thank Thulla - she's the one who set me on your trail.

26.speaker: Beldron
26.text: Glittering gods. I should've know that one was too damn stubborn to die.

66.speaker: Beldron
66.text: And yet the cult didn't clap you in chains. I'd like to learn that trick.

11.speaker: Beldron
11.text: We'll all be free yet. The Ironhands always find a way.

115.speaker: Lunkbug
115.text: I'm all right, I promise. I just wish...

135.speaker: Beldron
135.text: ... I know. I do too. But we're together - that's what matters.

94.speaker: Beldron
94.text: You. Thank you for trying to free us, at least. I thought you were with the cult.
94.context: NodeContext: Turning to player - still grim at his people's continuing status as slaves, but grateful that you TRIED to do something.

64.speaker: Beldron
64.text: Fah. Thought I'd have to breathe my last in Nere's stink.

72.speaker: Beldron
72.text: I've lost so much. Please, just - just let me be.

87.speaker: Beldron
87.text: Freedom. Or what passes for it.
87.context: NodeContext: Thrilled to be released, with a deep breath.

105.speaker: Beldron
105.text: Do the right thing. Kill Nere.
105.context: CinematicNodeContext: Leaning in and whisperingNodeContext: Leaning in and whispering

73.speaker: Beldron
73.context: CinematicNodeContext: Beldron returns to normal position and speaking tone.NodeContext: Beldron returns to normal position and speaking tone.

117.speaker: Beldron
117.text: Thought we'd leapt from frying pan to flame for a moment, there.

126.speaker: Beldron
126.text: You came through. I can't believe it. I owe you more than you know.

39.speaker: Beldron
39.text: I'm taking the rest of us 'cross the lake. Safer shores and all that.

134.speaker: Beldron
134.text: We'll be safer 'cross the Ebonlake. Then back to the city, Gaerdal Ironhand willing.
